I found this giraffe behind glass at the California Academy of Sciences in San Francisco. I was able to create the model using my SLR camera and 123D Catch desktop version.
He came out well despite the glass glare, which I tried to minimize. Also, the back part of the giraffe was against the wall, so that part isn't as detailed as the front.
Here is the textured capture on 123dapp.com: http://www.123dapp.com/3dp-Catch/giraffe/1357618

Model was created by 123D Catch using photographs from my SLR. I managed to heal up the holes and make it flat on the bottom with Meshmixer. I used an SLR and 123D Catch PC app to create this model from photographs. The lion was behind glass, so I couldn't get around to capture the other side.
I was able to use Meshmixer to mirror the good side to the missing side.
Shooting tips:
I would recommend to keep in mind to have the complete object in focus while shooting, eliminating any depth of field that can degrade the result. Also, shoot sequentially in small increments. A good rule of thumb is to shoot a 360 degree loop of 20-30 photos with the subject in full frame at same zoom. If the subject does not fit, then shoot two photographs from the same position with plenty of overlap.
Then another loop from a top down angle (if possible).
Remember not to move or rotate the object since 123D Catch also uses the surroundings to construct the scene. Ideally put the object on a newspaper or similar.
When you have your photos, make sure not to upload resolution higher than 3-6 megapixels.
Also, when shooting people, make sure they do not move whatsovever. Have them focus on a distant target (so eyes donâ€™t move) and it is easiest if they close their jaw/mouth so the facial muscles arenâ€™t moving.

I included all files - simple and enlarged version. I fogot to make a photo with a size comparison, so I included a picture with a 3D model of a euro coin. I did it all in sketchup, and I am happy how it turned out in the little time I spent on it. Probably max what is possible with a "daily earring" project unless I would do it full time ;-) NOTE: The colored image is the tiny model, due to the macro shot it looks a bit rough.

Regard when printing:
While th large one prints fine standing, the little one turns out better laying (but it requires more cleaning). Due to the high Z axis resolution the facial features look better - and less cleaning of those parts creates a smoother finish.

comments.text: Dude... Super glue is gonna do a way better job that hot glue on PLA. Cyanocrylic glues work best with PLA and don't generate heat that ends up slightly deforming the joint. Its less messy, only need a barely visible layer of it to permently bond it. You don't have a mess of glue to trim if you do it that way. Same with epoxy and gorilla glue, its not gonna work as well as super glue. Use the liquid, not gel. If you have problems with the white haze, bond the part and then coat in a thin layer of veggy oil or another non-stick substance. Then wipe/wash off when the glue sets. You also seem to be printing either too slow or too hot, that's where those ripples come from. It can also be from over extrusion (use a caliper for your filament, there's a procedure) or it could be that your Zhop is too tall.

author: warnweld

description.text: Lagerblock für Fenster-Jalousie
A wall mount for plastic wrap.

This is a wall mount for a roll of plastic wrap.
It uses a ~13 inch razor blade slide-cutter I saved from an old box of Kirkland plastic wrap. (...but not many people will have one of the slide-cutters.
An alternative is using the metal blade from the box of wrap.
Cut off the entire front cardboard panel, with the metal blade attached, from the empty box. The tall cardboard piece is adequately stiff and strong. Hot-melt glue it to the two end pieces after they are mounted on a wall.
It's not as 'clean' as using a slide, and makes it difficult to disassemble the project, but it does work.) This replacement roll is the 250 sq foot stuff I get from Walmart. Its cardboard tube has an internal diameter of just over 1.5 inches. The Left and Right bases, printed together, use 125 grams, required 2hours, 55m with Afinia defaults except for 0.40mm layers to save time.
The two end pieces (axles) take 50 min, 38 grams ABS.
All 4 pieces won't fit on the 5.5" x 5.5" Afinia platform, so two prints are required Parts are mounted with drywall anchors and short drywall screws. It's nice to be able to grab and pull the clingy, stretchy plastic wrap with both hands. Mounting it just above the counter top is great. I often prepare a lot of meals ahead of time, and sometimes do a lot of wrapping, and this is a real convenience.
Even If you don't make one, go buy a wall mount. You won't be sorry. These STLs are SAE / Imperial measurement files. To print with metric software, scale the parts larger by a factor of 25.4.

description.text:
Countless materials. Simply fix strings with a vise and tune it up. What is Vice Guitar? This is a new guitar using a vice. The neck and the body do not exist unlike other string instruments. This guitar works by fixing head, bridge and strings to an object. You can attach and stretch this device to any object that has certain length and solidness. It transforms things around you into your personal instruments, and you’ll discover a totally new vibrancy of unbeknown materials. Since Vice guitar put priority on the enjoyment of “instrument-fixing random materials, “playable-ness (whether easy to play or not)” is not in focus. If you really take care of “playable-ness”, why don’t you go out and explore your ideal material? You might run into unexpected things, or you might learn something more important than “playable-ness”. This practice of playing music by a random object you encounter, is to leave the emerging timbre to the attribute of the material. Taking this “timbre of material” as the “melody of environment”, I call this exploration of (the blessing of) melodies and this pursuit of the nature of playing music as “Vice Guitar Project”. website

description.text:
Author: Benedetto Antelami
Date: 1196/1270 AD

title: Asus EeeTop All-In-One PC Pole Mount

This is an indicator light for your bicycle or motor cycle. The light contains one LED, so need two of these to indicate both directions. The design is made such a way that any rain falling on it is guided away. If there is any condensations inside the light, it can drip out. It is important that the light is mounted with the correct side up. The screw holding front &back and the wire exit are located on or near the bottom side.. The light has a back and front that hinge together at the top, and are hold together with a screw on the bottom. In the STL download you find 4 variants of this light. The difference is where the wire enters the light: either side or bottom and left or right
The variants are thus:
  • Left side
  • Left bottom wire
  • Right bottom
  • Right side
    • The LED has hardly any cooling , so it can only be turned on a short time like an indicator function. It cannot be turned on for longer time because it will overheat quite quickly. So don't use it as rear light or so.

Print without support in either transparent naturel or transparent orange. I used ABS, but PLA will also work. You need a resistor to limit the current through the LED. I used a 22 ohm resistor at 12v operation. Because I did not have a 1w version in my junk box, I used 3x 68 ohm (1/4w) resistor in parallel. There are nut traps on the back: these are optional. If you like the mounting screw to be fixed to the light, please use them. Needed:
  • front and back printed (with same wire entry position!)
  • 1w Yellow LED (e.g. banggood http://www.banggood.com/Stunning-Highlight-LED-Night-Light-for-Multicopter-p-917959.html order the Yellow one )
  • 1 m3 nut and m3x10 screw to lock the front and back
  • 2x m3x25? screw+ nut and washers etc for mounting to the frame.
  • limiting resistor
  • some wire
    • The LED is pushed into the T slot. It is does not clamp or is to loose use you solder iron to melt it in place. To make a complete indicator you need a switch on your steering wheel, a flasher relay and a (12v) power source. A happy flashing to you !

A purge tower for priming your nozzle(s) in multicolor single-nozzle prints designed to work with Repetier Host V1.0.6 (slicing with Slic3r) This design was originally made for the Diamond Hotend:
http://reprap.org/wiki/Diamond_Hotend
It should however be beneficial for any printer capable of color mixing

primetower.scad is a simple script to generate several primetower stl-files, one for each extruder. Having the same point of origin the towers are aligned next to each other and when combined into a single AMF file using the "Combine multi-material STL files..." option in Slic3r 1.1.7 the output becomes a single multi-material structure. Alternavely follow the Diamond Hotend guide on combining STL-files: http://reprap.org/wiki/Diamond_Hotend#Combining_STL_files Using Repetier Host V1.0.6:
  • First add your desired amf object file using the encircled plus symbol from the right pane
  • Next add “primetower.amf” and scale it in the Z-direction to fit the object from step 1
  • Verify that the primetower is located behind the object to be printed as seen from View → Front View
    • More information can be found here: http://www.reprap.org/wiki/Repetier_Color_Mixing

comments.text: Although going with 100% infill probably would require some extruder calibration and very tall towers could suffer some bed adhesion issues... If you feel confident with these factors I don't really see any reason not to try it out. :)

comments.text: What i meant is that even if the printed object is hollow, say 10% infill, i still want the waste tower to be as condensed as possible as a 10% infill requires a very large surface for the new color to properly replace the old color used. And i would like to know if you knew whether the tower could be printed at higher infill, like 80-100%.

Ahh well, honestly I haven't found a way to have separate infill percentages for the towers which of course would be really nice to have. Also I have moved on with my career so I haven't spent a lot of time researching printing techniques lately so I guess I owe you an answer on that one.
I recommend that you direct your inquiry to the Repetier community and see if any of the developers are working on this or have it in the pipeline. That way you might directly or indirectly help bringing forward that feature.

comments.text: If I don't have a 3D printer myself and I want to have a look how many cm3 it is to print, in which (free) software can I best do this? If I import it into NetFabb it is a filled object and I do not see how to make it hollow as a vase here. If I import it in Makerware I see it as a hollow vase but I don(t see how to calculate the number of slices, printing volume (cm3 and printing time?
comments.author: robin35

comments.text: Printing volume & time is fully dependent on printer settings (mainly the % of infill and the printing speed the person printing the object sets in their slicing software). On my printer, using 25% infill, this prints in ~2.5 hours, using 2.8 meters of plastic, but then I do have my printer set slower to get better print quality. If you use services like makexyz or 3dhubs, this shouldn't cost you more than $10-15 to get printed. I'd recommend my shop on those sites, but my printer is currently offline due to a move :)

title: Molding form for the body interaction vibration board

description.text:
With this 3d printed form you can overmold a pcb - in this case a board with vibration motor and LiPo .The vibration is more comfortable and less noisy compared to pure 3d printed cases.Silicone cases are easy to clean. The form was constructed for the body interaction board. More Information:
www.bodyinteraction.com

• Print out the 3D form. The surface should be as smooth as possible. Take some tinkering wire and fix the two parts of the form.
  • Fix LiPo and vibration motor. Put some glue on the board. First secure the cables of the vibration motor on the board. Then put the LiPo above. The cables of the motor are between the LiPO and the board.
  • Put some plasticine on the switch top. This should prevent the silicone to flow into the switch. After the moulding remove the plasticine.
  • Put some glue or tape over the holes of the USB port. It is very important that the silicone doesn’t flow into the USB port or between port and connector. If this happens it is hard to unplug the USB connector without destroying the female USB plug on the board. If this happens it is impossible to recharge the battery.
  • Connect the USB port with a USB cable. Now fix the cable with tinkering wire to the form. Check carefully that the board (and motor) doesn’t touch the form.
  • Now mix the both components of the silicone. Pour the silicone very slowly into the form. Air bubbles could be problem if you don’t have a vacuum tube to remove the bubbles. Blowing air into the form could help to remove at least some of the bubbles.
  • When the silicone is solid remove the form. Remove overhanging part. Remove the platicine from the switch. Carefully remove the USB plug – don’t force it. The board could be seriously damaged.
    More details on http://bodyinteraction.com/cases/how-to-molding-a-silicone-case-for-the-bi1-board-with-a-3d-printed-form/

author: pinklover123

description.text:
This lioness can be found hanging out at the California Academy of Sciences in San Francisco. I used an SLR camera and 123D Catch PC to create the 3D model from photographs.
Here is the original project and textured version at 123dapp.com: http://www.123dapp.com/3dp-Catch/Lion-Capture/1357701

I used an SLR and 123D Catch PC app to create this model from photographs. The lion was behind glass, so I couldn't get around to capture the other side.
I was able to use Meshmixer to mirror the good side to the missing side.
Shooting tips:
I would recommend to keep in mind to have the complete object in focus while shooting, eliminating any depth of field that can degrade the result. Also, shoot sequentially in small increments. A good rule of thumb is to shoot a 360 degree loop of 20-30 photos with the subject in full frame at same zoom. If the subject does not fit, then shoot two photographs from the same position with plenty of overlap.
Then another loop from a top down angle (if possible).
Remember not to move or rotate the object since 123D Catch also uses the surroundings to construct the scene. Ideally put the object on a newspaper or similar.
When you have your photos, make sure not to upload resolution higher than 3-6 megapixels.
Also, when shooting people, make sure they do not move whatsovever. Have them focus on a distant target (so eyes donâ€™t move) and it is easiest if they close their jaw/mouth so the facial muscles arenâ€™t moving.

title: Not-Stereo iPhone Dock
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I derived this one from two different things:
Phonecone iPhone4 version by eagleapex
(http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:6348) and;
Enhanced iPhone Dock by RobertHunt
(http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:6931)
I loved the idea and the retro look of the Phonecone so I made one and since I don't own an iPhone I took it to the park where my dog walking friends get together. They only had iPhone 3s and the thing would not fit them but they loved it. Then one of them said that she would like to have it sit up on her desk.
That is when I found the Enhanced iPhone Dock and I built one. But the iPhones 3s would not stand up without the connector and in the process I also discovered that the iPhone is stereo.
So... I thought, what a great project to practice my Blender skills on.
I made the Enhanced iPhone Dock taller, with the holding space a bit narrower and added two holes that send the sound to the front where the cones from the Phonecone fit. The stand fits both the iPhone 3 and 4.
It sounds great! And my iPhone 3 friends are delighted.
OK, so I found out that the iPhone is not stereo so I've uploaded a version for the iPhone4 with only one horn. I have not made one but it should work.

Build the Dock and two cones and glue them in place making sure that the Dock sits flat.
Put music on and rock!
New instructions as per RobertHunt suggestion: Build the two hole dock and one cone. Then if you have the iPhone3 put the horn on the left, for the iPhone4 put it on the right. For the iPhone4, you can build the one hole version.
You can still rock!

This is the Diamond Hotend kit that I developed while working for RepRap.me Since then I have moved on with a completely different job and this thing will not be updated any further by me, therefore If you have any suggestions or questions please forward them to [email protected] * This is an OpenSCAD script which holds a mock-up of the metal parts of the Diamond Hotend. The script also holds routines to generate the structure (also denoted Cooling Shield) needed for appropriate cooling of the Diamond Hotend's three E3D HeatSinks using by a single high-output 50 mm fan. Furthermore it has an option for a 5015 blower pendant to allow for active cooling of the printed material.
Enable this by setting:
blower_enable = true; diamond_metal_parts_only.stl
Metal parts mock up made for the purpose of subtraction from your custom design.
This part is made with the scad script by defining:
assembled = false;
metalPartsOnly = false; The above configurations have been exported into STL-files.
Please feel free to fetch the OpenSCAD script and make as many derivates to fit your printer(s) as you like, but please keep a reference to this thing. For further information please visit http://reprap.org/wiki/Diamond_Hotend
or http://reprap.me/extruder/diamond-hotend.html

Diamond_Hotend page on reprap org has a link to Diamond_Nozzle.pdf with drawings and specification of distances. Each M6 mounting hole for cooling towers are leaning out 28 degrees from the centre and are spaced 120 degrees apart. From the origin (the point where all the lines meet) there is a distance of 24 mm to the beginning of each M6 threaded hole (which itself is 6 mm deep measured from the most distant point on the upper surface) Dimensions of the E3D LiteV6 can be found on the E3D homepage. Of course the diamond_hotend_assembly.scad also contains all this information (if you can decode it) :-) FAQ:
Q: is there a nozzle .stl available? A: Not really -but if you
  • download and install the latest version of OpenSCAD
  • open "diamond_hotend_assembly.scad"
  • set "metalPartsOnly = true;" on line 14
  • add "//" on line 87 so that it reads "//coldend();"
  • hit F6 to render and click "File"-"Export"-"Export as STL..."
    • then you can generate your own "nozzle.stl" :)
  • Or you could just take a look at "diamond_cooler_metal_parts_only.stl"

comments.text: Please note that it is not possible to achieve full color with 3-in-1-out diamond hot end. Even if you feed it with CMY filaments, you will still lack the K component for printing in pitch black, and what is way more important - the W component. When you print with a CMYK ink jet or laser printer on paper, the paper is white. When you print with CMY from a diamond hotend, there is no white base and so you can't achieve light hues. I know that currently reprap.me offers a 5-in-1-out hotend that should solve this problem (provided that it can actually evenly mix the incoming colors, which I doubt), however you will need a compatible control board and a compatible slicer, which I don't know of.

description.text:
This simple water wheel is the first version of a project my daughter is working on for her school maker club.  
Space for up to 12 scoops.  (4, 6, or 12)  
Everything snaps together very tightly.  
Center hole for 1/4" bearing  
Made with Blender!  More to come

• Print one hub (0.2mm - 0.3mm layer height, 15% infill)

  • Print 4, 6, or 12 Spoons (0.4mm layer height, 15% infill)

  • Snap together.

Spoons print quickly in PLA at 0.4mm height with no major issues.  I tried the scoops at 0.2 and 0.3 layer heights first, but found no noticeable difference to the 0.4 other than it taking half the time to print.

• Make it lighter
    Add open holes to hub
     Convert hub to spokes
    Thin the spoon walls
     Angle the spoon bottom to use less plastic but keep same volume
  • Add teeth to hub allowing Spoon to be custom positioned

Hold a caliper and 3 hex keys neatly on the front of the makerbot.  Now I can find them!
Everyone needs a caliper.  Much easier to read a digital display than guess fractions of a mm.  The hex keys come with the makerbot.  Seemed a good holder to put them all together in one place.

This was my first go at using Solid Works.  Far easier than expected!  :)

3mm for the top holes and the one at the back
4mm for the hex key holes
6mm most the way through from the front Fix to makerbot with origional nut and screw, then drill additional holes and fix.

Topography of a lake and mountain made in blender using a heightmap to displace vertices. It ended up being a great exercise for my new ToM and looks pretty awesome. I printed mine at .3mm thickness and would be interested to see it in different colors, larger build or smaller thickness. I made this several years ago and have lost the original heightmap, if I stumble across it I'll upload it as well. The STL file ended up being fairly massive, if anyone knows how to drop it down without any detail loss I'll do it. The blender file includes an object or two that I was using in a water simulation and thought I'd leave them in should anyone care to play around with it.

title: iPhone Camera Stand for Time Lapse and Still Photos

description.text:
I originally designed this stand to hold my iPhone 5 so I could take time lapse photos of a culture in a petri dish. This iPhone stand holds the phone steady with the focal length required to fill the field of view with a clear, focused image.   
It works perfectly for time lapse photography, but can also be used to photograph any flat or nearly flat object that fits under the stand.   
Ironically, it works perfectly for making online electronic deposits of bank checks that require a photo of the front and back. Time lapse is a lot more fun, but this definitely saves a trip to the ATM if your bank supports online deposits.

title: 25mm ball clamp for Underwater Photography strobe arm

description.text:
Similar to INON, Ikelite, Sea&Sea, etc  
25mm (or 1 inch for the Americans) ball joint for use with a underwater strobe arm.  
These things are typically anodized Aluminum and $25 each for the cheap Chinese versions and $50 for the USA company ones (Ikelite et al).  Since you need 3 on each strobe arm, you can save some by making your own.   
Also:  since they are made of ABS, they weigh less underwater (less weight, more buoyancy due to higher volume as plastic is not as strong as metal)  
NOTE: UNTESTED with branded equipment.  Tested only with my own printed ball joints.  Locks pretty tight, but not 100% perfectly rigid as would occur with metal arms/joints.  
IF YOU MAKE THIS, READ THE INSTRUCTIONS !!!

1) Print at 100% infill in ABS with the mating surfaces on top. Support needed for the back. Layer height is 0.1mm. DON'T THINK YOU CAN SKIMP ON THIS!
2) The bolt is a hex head M6 x 55mm LNG, 316 stainless
3) Use a Nylon washer between the Handle and the clamp. 12mm OD x 1.5m THK
4) Heat stake in a M6 x 12deep brass insert into the other end. Get it from McMaster-Carr. Part 94180A373. Careful, the M6 comes in two lengths, you want the 12.7mm one.
5) Spring from Amazon supply. I used part number B005S4IFDM, but you might want a stronger one.

description.text:
This sub-irrigated planter uses a 16-oz latte cup as a water reservoir. Friendly design for the kitchen countertop or windowsill. Comments/suggestions welcome! Plant friendly

  • Sub-irrigation provides constant moisture and prevents soil from being compacted by top-watering, and holes provide aeration to roots. Optional attachment site for a gooseneck LED lamp allows happier plants in low-light areas.

    • Human friendly

  • Large inlet makes it easy to water, and big reservoir keeps it alive during vacations/forgetful weeks. You can use a small G-clamp to attach the base to your counter edge or windowsill and prevent plantastrophes.

    • Printer friendly

  • No support needed for printing. Water is held in the latte cup, so no worries about leaky prints.

What you will need: Printed parts (planter base and top). Consider food-safe filament for growing edibles. 16-oz Latte cup--This planter was designed around a 16-oz Dart-brand clear plastic cup. The cup is ~137mm tall and has a max diameter of ~98mm. There's a few mm wiggle room in the design for similar cups. (Design could be scaled to accommodate other containers) Wicking--the sub-irrigated planter (SIP) relies on a wick to draw water up from the reservoir to the potting mix. Capillary action! Strips of a cotton T-shirt work fine, so does nylon rope. Put a knot in it and feed through the hole in the planter top. It should be long enough to reach to the bottom of the cup. Potting mix--Don't use regular dirt or even commercial "garden soil", you need something with high water transport such as potting mix or coconut coir. Optional G-clamp for attachment--can buy one, or print one (such as http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:30040) Optional extra lighting--the planter base has an optional site to attach a gooseneck USB-pwered LED lamp, such as the Daffodil ULT05. You will need 4x M3 bolts to screw the printed "little clip" part to the base. Plant--Choose a plant that will be happy with your lighting conditions. Basil and thyme need tons of light, chives and cilantro need moderate amount, some houseplants need less. If you are using additional lighting, most plants are happy with 24/7 light but some such as spider plant are not Plant care note--Due to high humidity within the cup, you may see development of hanging roots coming out of planter holes. Recommended to cut them off to encourage more healthy root growth within potting mix.

title: Cover for Stainless Steel Pepper or Salt Shakers

description.text: I like to use Stainless Steel Dredgers for Pepper or Salt Shakers for cooking. They need a way to easily identify their contents, so I made covers with a letter and a handle. They work extremely well and look good too. Eventually I will make one for a powered sugar and for a flour dredge. The cover would be handy for spices as well.

The cover fits very tightly so that it does not slip off as it's being used. After printing, heat or dip it in hot water to assist in putting it over the dredge. Dredges are available in restaurant supply stores or on line at Amazon.  
I print these with a raft and support because of the handle.

description.text:
This is a trick opening box!
Following the proper steps, you will be able to reopen it. I've added some clues on how the puzzle work in my blog: http://wp.me/p3gI7M-4V Note: You need two 1/2" (12.7mm) diameter marbles or ball bearing to operate the mechanism inside.

This puzzle is clearly more complex than my previous one. To get the best feeling the pieces have to be tight, so I've reduced the clearance to 0.5mm in the sliding areas. Print the following parts:
  • 1x box
  • 1x Door
  • 2x Side Panel
  • 2x Keys
  • 2x Marbles (optional)
    • Look the second picture for assembly instructions. I've tried the reduce the over-hangs on most of the pieces to ease the print. It's still a "work in progress" as I couldn't print it yet and I have a concern on the durability of the 2 top notches in the box piece to slide the door. They may break if care is not taken while shutting the box. I have to thanks Ttsalo for his idea of springs using a rod. In a sense this box is a sort of padlock where the key is replaced by the marbles. I've included the STL for the 1/2" marbles, but I would recommend to use a glass or a ball-bearing. Keep me updated if you try to print this!

author: AwesomeA

description.text:
This is one of my most talked-about designs, particularly in supermarkets where people are always asking where they can buy one. It slips onto the top of a grocery cart and holds my iPad (would work for other tablets too) so my shopping list is easily to hand while shopping.  
The Mk4 design attempts to make it sturdier and better able to fit more carts. I've lengthened the vertical so it better supports a tablet, moved the 'legs' down a little, and turned them to a sharper angle, so on carts where the Mk3 tends to leave it tilting forward, it should hold up better. There are stronger supports on the legs, a deeper cut-out for the button, and curved corners.

You may need interior supports for the thumb cut-out. You will probably also need to pull out all the stops on avoiding curl if printing in PLA. I was never able to make that work, but it prints fine for me in ABS. Just means I can't leave in the car in summer or it will warp.  
Please post an I Made One and tell me which approach you used.

title: A collection of tire tread rings

description.text:
Hi- Here's a collection of four rings with different tire tread designs. Two basically generic treads, and two treads based (loosely) on the 2013 Pirelli intermediate and full wet Formula 1 race treads.
The rings all have an inside diameter of .67" and an outside diameter of 1.07" and are all .45" wide.
I'll put some pictures up as soon as the rings are done printing. Enjoy!

The printer we are lucky enough to have at Kishwaukee College in Illinois is a Dimension uPrint SE Plus. We use the .stl manipulation and print management software that comes with the printer called CatalystEX, and we are currently running version 4.3 of that. These rings were all printed with a resolution of .010", solid infill, and with support material generation set to "smart".

ScribbleJ is getting married!  
As I've never been one to wear jewelry, I have no idea what my ring size might be.  You can measure it with a string or something, but that's a horrible method since rings are far more rigid and regular...
You can go to a jeweler, but since I fully intend to buy the rings online from e.g. Amazon, bothering some salesperson for a sizing seems dishonest -- and of course dealing with salespeople is it's own special hell.
So I thought I'd whip up a quick OpenSCAD script to print simple rings in a few sizes, you can try them on and find out what fits right.
Not a WIP - but I'll post photos after I've printed some.

• Load up the .scad file in OpenSCAD.
    • It's well-documented, but here's a copy of the parametric settings so you can see what's involved without downloading it: // set ring_w to width of ring.
    ring_w = 8;
    // ring_thick = radius of ring
    ring_thick = 2; // num_rings = how many rings to print
    num_rings = 5;
    // print_sizes = array of the ring sizes you want printed
    print_sizes = [6, 6.5, 7, 7.5, 8]; // Spacing of rings
    rings_per_row = 3;
    ring_space = 25;

comments.text: I've actually been wanting to do this so I can ship customers rings sizers that they don't have to worry about mailing back.  I make lots of rings, and usually am shipping them.

comments.text: Interesting.  I printed one run of whole sizes, 6 through 15.  The size 6 is one size to small, by size 15 it's about 1.25 sizes to small.  Would it make more sense to add a "fudge factor" multiplier in the SCAD file, or change all the dimensions?

comments.text: Thanks for trying it out before I could find time!  It makes more sense to me to add a scaling factor - the scaling factor can be set to scale inversely with the size...  let me take care of that and post a new version.

comments.text: I added a simple scaling factor based on your two data points.  I still haven't printed any of this myself (shame on me!) but I've uploaded the version with scaling included.

My second go at a coffee cup design in Autodesk 123Design. See the first one here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:719140. This one prints better with some support under the base of the handle. In Cura you can select to add supports from build plate only, as opposed to supports everywhere. If you want to use it for real with hot coffee, I suggest you print with a "food safe" filament with a good thermal resistance such as Nylon or Colorfabb XT (the one I used here). PLA and ABS are not recommended as PLA could deform with hot coffee and ABS is not "chemically friendly" for food use (neither PLA is, by the way).

This is a rotating spice rack, and also my second entry into the #CountertopChallenge. The rack itself prints in three pieces, but doesn't require much assembly at all. Put the bottom rack on the bottom lip of the base, then the top rack on the top lip. Depending on how many spices you want to store, print out that many of the custom shakers. The rack can hold up to twelve. Each piece is going to take quite a while to print, but I personally think that it's worth it! If a piece doesn't fit on your print bed and you need to scale it down, SCALE EVERY PIECE DOWN BY THE SAME FACTOR. Otherwise the pieces won't fit together the way that they should. Enjoy your spice rack, please comment if you have any issues!
